H0.text: Cell-level organization is the arrangement exemplified by sponges, where different cells are specialized for different functions but each cell works alone.

H1.text: Independent organization is the arrangement exemplified by sponges, where different cells are specialized for different functions yet each cell works alone.

H2.text: Commensalism is the type of arrangement exemplified by sponges, where different cells are specialized for different functions, but each cell works alone.

H3.text: Organ-level organization is the type of arrangement exemplified by sponges, where different cells are specialized for different functions but each cell works alone.

A4.text: 18 distinct cell types have been identified.

A5.text: Sponges can control the water flow by various combinations of wholly or partially closing the osculum and ostia (the intake pores) and varying the beat of the flagella, and may shut it down if there is a lot of sand or silt in the water.

A6.text: Animals have evolved a considerable diversity of cell types in a multicellular body (100–150 different cell types), compared with 10–20 in plants and fungi.

A7.text: Multicellularity allows an organism to exceed the size limits normally imposed by diffusion: single cells with increased size have a decreased surface-to-volume ratio and have difficulty absorbing sufficient nutrients and transporting them throughout the cell.
